text:
Hey all! Would love to hear how you measure productivity from a content production perspective. :thinking_face:

Background: my team isn't deadline-driven, so we have a point system where content is worth a certain amount of points based on the work involved, with the expectation that everyone hits a certain goal each month (measured on a 2-month avg.).

Problem: I'm getting a lot of feedback from my writers and editors that the expectations in place with this system are stressful and impacting the quality of the work they do. Any thoughts?

elements.text: Hey all! Would love to hear how you measure productivity from a content production perspective.

Background: my team isn't deadline-driven, so we have a point system where content is worth a certain amount of points based on the work involved, with the expectation that everyone hits a certain goal each month (measured on a 2-month avg.).

Problem: I'm getting a lot of feedback from my writers and editors that the expectations in place with this system are stressful and impacting the quality of the work they do. Any thoughts?

text: Marketing needs deadlines, otherwise content wouldn't get put out on a consistent basis. I actually like the points system that you outlined because that could definitely help if emergencies happened. Before getting rid of the points system have you thought about increasing the points that certain activities are worth, increasing the timeline for the average, or creating different points systems based on the strengths of your team? I think there are ways to make it work while taking your teams thoughts into consideration and keeping marketing consistent.

elements.text: Marketing needs deadlines, otherwise content wouldn't get put out on a consistent basis. I actually like the points system that you outlined because that could definitely help if emergencies happened. Before getting rid of the points system have you thought about increasing the points that certain activities are worth, increasing the timeline for the average, or creating different points systems based on the strengths of your team? I think there are ways to make it work while taking your teams thoughts into consideration and keeping marketing consistent.

text: Do they understand why they’re writing something (i.e. connecting their work to larger company/team goals or mission) or are they just picking up assignments to get productivity points?

elements.text: Do they understand why they’re writing something (i.e. connecting their work to larger company/team goals or mission) or are they just picking up assignments to get productivity points?

text:
i'd dig in further in 1:1s on what exactly is causing the stress. could it be a lack of clarity on how the system works, a feeling that the points aren't fair, unrealistic expectations, or something else? can't solve the problem without fully understanding it

points system sounds interesting but i agree with <@U01J85VRKF1> that marketing needs deadlines. you can account for variable content with deadlines (e.g. don't schedule 2 huge pillar articles to go live in 1 week)

sometimes a lack of deadlines can actually cause stress because people aren't clear on the priority of things or what they should work on next

text: I remember a systems thinking adage that I used to use a lot in my past life as a management consultant (not sure who originally said it, maybe Peter Drucker) that "if you introduce a KPI for a team they WILL hit that KPI, even if they have to burn the company to the ground to do it."  I mention this because that goal sounds volume-based, and the team sounds craft-minded, which would result in a stressful friction between a "quantity over quality" KPI and individuals that value "quality over quantity."  So perhaps they're stressed because they're trying to meet their own personal standards while hitting their externally set points goal.

elements.text: I remember a systems thinking adage that I used to use a lot in my past life as a management consultant (not sure who originally said it, maybe Peter Drucker) that "if you introduce a KPI for a team they WILL hit that KPI, even if they have to burn the company to the ground to do it."  I mention this because that goal sounds volume-based, and the team sounds craft-minded, which would result in a stressful friction between a "quantity over quality" KPI and individuals that value "quality over quantity."  So perhaps they're stressed because they're trying to meet their own personal standards while hitting their externally set points goal.

text: Anyway, I mention that as context for my personal take, which is that I'm generally not a fan, from an org theory perspective of "productivity goals" for knowledge workers, since they're usually some variant of "widgets produced per hour" and a proxy for some other goal (e.g. the goal of the content program probably isn't _actually_ to produce a certain number of words, but a certain outcome, like qualified leads).  Is there a goal you can set for them that's more results-oriented and in line with the purpose of the content?

elements.text: Anyway, I mention that as context for my personal take, which is that I'm generally not a fan, from an org theory perspective of "productivity goals" for knowledge workers, since they're usually some variant of "widgets produced per hour" and a proxy for some other goal (e.g. the goal of the content program probably isn't
to produce a certain number of words, but a certain outcome, like qualified leads).  Is there a goal you can set for them that's more results-oriented and in line with the purpose of the content?

text: Some great feedback here. I would always make sure you know why you are creating content in the first place, work to understand what the goal of content is within your digital system and figure out how to create better processes to improve productivity - productivity is not necessarily something I would suggest measuring vs. as <@URAV154AV> said, why are they writing what they're writing. Are things campaign based, etc. Hope this helps!
